conclusion: Analyze the motion of the conductor rod in the magnetic field and calculate the induced EMF to determine the power of the external force.

The image shows a semi-circular conductor frame with radius r, centered at O. A conductor rod OC can slide on the frame and is connected to a resistor R at O. The frame is in a uniform magnetic field with induction intensity B. The rod rotates uniformly with angular velocity ω.
The conductor rod OC rotates in a uniform magnetic field with induction intensity B.
As the rod moves, it induces an EMF due to the change in magnetic flux through the area enclosed by the rod.
The area enclosed by the rod is part of the semi-circular frame with radius r. The angle of rotation of the rod is θ = ωt.
The magnetic flux through this area is given by Φ = (1/2) B r^2 θ.
The induced EMF in the rod is ε = -dΦ/dt = -(1/2) B r^2 ω.
The power P of the external force doing work to rotate the rod is given by the rate of change of the rod's kinetic energy.
Since the resistances are negligible, the power is equal to the induced EMF times the current I in the circuit.
The power P is thus P = ε I = (1/2) B r^2 ω^2.
